div1.p:
Have you seen, or heard of, on the north or middle coast of Brazil,
any disease which might be Schistomiasis Mansonii (Bilharsia)? It is
common about Caracas and, I am told, in other places in Venezuela. It
would be known in Brazil, I think, as “o bicho”. as designation which,
in one or the other gender, was formerly given in Brazil to a number
of diseases, from yellow fever to measles and scurvy, according--one
judges--to the presence of lumbricoid worms or other (“bichos”) found on autopsy.

Sigeud (Du Climat et du Maladies du Brazil." 1844) mentionts “o bicho” it as pre-
valent in Brazil at that time, imported from Angola. His description
would make it an acute proctitis followed at times by gangrene and death.
The specific treatment was stimulating enemata of lemon juice and Rounded car-
damon seed (“Roinre eurago'”), which, if retained, the prognosis was fatal. If it could
not be retained--i. e. gangrene had not progressed far, recovery was
possible. His book should not be rare, as it is not old.
